member.name: T:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.LoadBalancingClient
member.summary: This class implements the Photon LoadBalancing workflow by using a LoadBalancingPeer. It keeps a state and will automatically execute transitions between the Master and Game Servers.
member.remarks: This class (and the Player class) should be extended to implement your own game logic. You can override CreatePlayer as "factory" method for Players and return your own Player instances. The State of this class is essential to know when a client is in a lobby (or just on the master) and when in a game where the actual gameplay should take place. Extension notes: An extension of this class should override the methods of the IPhotonPeerListener, as they are called when the state changes. Call base.method first, then pick the operation or state you want to react to and put it in a switch-case. We try to provide demo to each platform where this api can be used, so lookout for those.

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.LoadBalancingClient.Connect(System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String,ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.AuthenticationValues)
member.summary: Starts the "process" to connect to the master server. Relevant connection-values parameters can be set via parameters.
member.remarks:
The process to connect includes several steps: the actual connecting, establishing encryption, authentification (of app and optionally the user) and joining a lobby (if AutoJoinLobby is true).
Instead of providing all these parameters, you can also set the individual properties of a client before calling Connect().
Users can connect either anonymously or use "Custom Authentication" to verify each individual player's login. Custom Authentication in Photon uses external services and communities to verify users. While the client provides a user's info, the service setup is done in the Photon Cloud Dashboard. The parameter authValues will set this.CustomAuthenticationValues and use them in the connect process.
To connect to the Photon Cloud, a valid AppId must be provided. This is shown in the Photon Cloud Dashboard. https://cloud.exitgames.com/dashboard Connecting to the Photon Cloud might fail due to: - Network issues (OnStatusChanged() StatusCode.ExceptionOnConnect) - Region not available (OnOperationResponse() for OpAuthenticate with ReturnCode == ErrorCode.InvalidRegion) - Subscription CCU limit reached (OnOperationResponse() for OpAuthenticate with ReturnCode == ErrorCode.MaxCcuReached) More about the connection limitations: http://doc.exitgames.com/photon-cloud/SubscriptionErrorCases/#cat-references
member.param: Set a master server address instead of using the default. Uses default if null or empty.
Your application's name or the AppID assigned by Photon Cloud (as listed in Dashboard). Uses default if null or empty.
Can be used to separate users by their client's version (useful to add features without breaking older clients). Uses default if null or empty.
Optional name for this player. Provide a unique (!) userID to use the Friend Finding feature. Uses default if null or empty.
Set the AuthParameters property to use Custom Authentication (see above). Attempts anonymous auth if null.
member.returns: If the operation could be send (can be false for bad server urls).

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.LoadBalancingClient.Service
member.summary: This method excutes dispatches all incoming commands and sends anything in the outgoing queues via DispatchIncomingCommands and SendOutgoingCommands.
member.remarks:
The Photon client libraries are designed to fit easily into a game or application. The application is in control of the context (thread) in which incoming events and responses are executed and has full control of the creation of UDP/TCP packages.
Sending packages and dispatching received messages are two separate tasks. Service combines them into one method at the cost of control. It calls DispatchIncomingCommands and SendOutgoingCommands.
Call this method regularly (2..20 times a second).
This will Dispatch ANY received commands (unless a reliable command in-order is still missing) and events AND will send queued outgoing commands. Fewer calls might be more effective if a device cannot send many packets per second, as multiple operations might be combined into one package.
member.example:
You could replace Service by:
while (DispatchIncomingCommands()); //Dispatch until everything is Dispatched... SendOutgoingCommands(); //Send a UDP/TCP package with outgoing messages

members.member:
\deprecated We introduced OpJoinOrCreateRoom to make the parameter createIfNotExists obsolete. Use either OpJoinRoom or OpJoinOrCreateRoom.
Joins a room by name and sets this player's properties. Optionally, a room can be created if not existing already.
Join will try to enter a room by roomName. If the room is full or closed, this will fail. If the room is not existing, JoinRoom will also fail by default.
You can set createIfNotExists to true to make the server instantly create the room if it doesn't exist. This makes it easier to get into the same room when several players exchanged a roomName already: Any player can try to join or create the room in one step - it doesn't matter who's first.
If the room is created due to createIfNotExists, the LocalPlayer.ID will be 1 and LocalPlayer.IsMasterClient will be true as well.
This overrides the LoadBalancingPeer.OpJoinRoom to keep a state.
The name of the room to join. Must be existing already, open and non-full or can't be joined. If true, the server will attempt to create a room. If the operation could be sent (has to be connected).

They will be attached to the specified lobby (by name and type). Use null as lobbyName to attach the room to the default lobby. Multiple lobbies can help separate players by map or skill or game type. Each room can only be found in one lobby (no matter if defined by name and type or as default).
The response depends on the server the peer is connected to: Master will return a Game Server toon connect to. Game Server will return the Room's data. This is an async request which triggers a OnOperationResponse() call.

The name to create a room with. Must be unique and not in use or can't be created. If null, the server will assign a GUID as name. Shows the room in the lobby's room list. Keeps players from joining the room (or opens it to everyone). Max players before room is considered full (but still listed). Custom properties to apply to the room on creation (use string-typed keys but short ones). Defines the custom room properties that get listed in the lobby. Null defaults to "none", a string[0]. Name of the lobby this game gets added to. Default: null, attached to default lobby. Lobbies are unique per lobbyName plus lobbyType, so the same name can be used when several types are existing. Type of the (named)lobby this game gets added to. Defines how long (in milliseconds) a player can be disconnected (thus being inactive) before being removed from a game (for good). Defines how long the room will stay in memory of Photon until it gets cleaned up. Indirectly this also defines how long players can return. Turnbased games get stored/persisted after this timeout. If the operation could be sent (has to be connected).

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.LoadBalancingClient.OpLeaveRoom
member.summary: Leaves the CurrentRoom and returns to the Master server (back to the lobby). OpLeaveRoom skips execution when the room is null or the server is not GameServer or the client is disconnecting from GS already. OpLeaveRoom returns false in those cases and won't change the state, so check return of this method.
member.remarks: This method actually is not an operation per se. It sets a state and calls Disconnect(). This is is quicker than calling OpLeave and then disconnect (which also triggers a leave).
member.returns: If the current room could be left (impossible while not in a room).

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.LoadBalancingClient.OpLeaveRoom(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Leaves the CurrentRoom and returns to the Master server (back to the lobby). OpLeaveRoom skips execution when the room is null or the server is not GameServer or the client is disconnecting from GS already. OpLeaveRoom returns false in those cases and won't change the state, so check return of this method.
member.remarks: This method actually is not an operation per se. It sets a state and calls Disconnect(). This is is quicker than calling OpLeave and then disconnect (which also triggers a leave).
member.returns: If the current room could be left (impossible while not in a room).

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.LoadBalancingClient.OpFindFriends(System.String[])
member.summary: Request the rooms and online status for a list of friends. All clients should set a unique UserId before connecting. The result is available in this.FriendList.
member.remarks:
Used on Master Server to find the rooms played by a selected list of users. The result will be stored in LoadBalancingClient.FriendList, which is null before the first server response.
Users identify themselves by setting a UserId in the LoadBalancingClient instance. This will send the ID in OpAuthenticate during connect (to master and game servers). Note: Changing a player's name doesn't make sense when using a friend list.
The list of usernames must be fetched from some other source (not provided by Photon).
Internal: The server response includes 2 arrays of info (each index matching a friend from the request): ParameterCode.FindFriendsResponseOnlineList = bool[] of online states ParameterCode.FindFriendsResponseRoomIdList = string[] of room names (empty string if not in a room)
member.param: Array of friend's names (make sure they are unique).
member.returns: If the operation could be sent (requires connection).

member.summary: Send an event with custom code/type and any content to the other players in the same room.

member.param: Identifies this type of event (and the content). Your game's event codes can start with 0.
Any serializable datatype (including Hashtable like the other OpRaiseEvent overloads).
If this event has to arrive reliably (potentially repeated if it's lost).
Contains (slightly) less often used options. If you pass null, the default options will be used.

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.LoadBalancingClient.OpWebRpc(System.String,System.Object)
member.summary: This operation makes Photon call your custom web-service by path/name with the given parameters (converted into JSon).
member.remarks:
This is a "Photon Turnbased" feature and you have to setup your Photon Cloud Application prior to use.
The response by Photon will call OnOperationResponse() with Code: OperationCode.WebRpc. It's important to understand that the OperationResponse tells you if the WebRPC could be called or not but the content of the response will contain the values the web-service sent (if any). If the web-service could not execute the request, it might return another error and a message. This is inside of the (wrapping) OperationResponse. The class WebRpcResponse is a helper-class that extracts the most valuable content from the WebRPC response.
See the Turnbased Feature Overview for a short intro. http://doc.exitgames.com/en/turnbased/current/getting-started/feature-overview

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.LoadBalancingClient.DisconnectedCause
member.summary: Summarizes (aggregates) the different causes for disconnects of a client.
member.remarks: A disconnect can be caused by: errors in the network connection or some vital operation failing (which is considered "high level"). While operations always trigger a call to OnOperationResponse, connection related changes are treated in OnStatusChanged. The DisconnectCause is set in either case and summarizes the causes for any disconnect in a single state value which can be used to display (or debug) the cause for disconnection.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.LoadBalancingClient.UserId
member.summary: An ID for this user. Sent in OpAuthenticate when you connect. If not set, the PlayerName is applied during connect.
member.remarks:
On connect, if the UserId is null or empty, the client will copy the PlayName to UserId. If PlayerName is not set either (before connect), the server applies a temporary ID which stays unknown to this client and other clients.
The UserId is what's used in FindFriends and for fetching data for your account (with WebHooks e.g.).
By convention, set this ID before you connect, not while being connected. There is no error but the ID won't change while being connected.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.LoadBalancingClient.FriendList
member.summary: List of friends, their online status and the room they are in. Null until initialized by OpFindFriends response.
member.remarks: Do not modify this list! It's internally handled by OpFindFriends and meant as read-only. The value of FriendListAge gives you a hint how old the data is. Don't get this list more often than useful (> 10 seconds). In best case, keep the list you fetch really short. You could (e.g.) get the full list only once, then request a few updates only for friends who are online. After a while (e.g. 1 minute), you can get the full list again.

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.LoadBalancingPeer.OpChangeGroups(System.Byte[],System.Byte[])
member.summary: Operation to handle this client's interest groups (for events in room).
member.remarks:
Note the difference between passing null and byte[0]: null won't add/remove any groups. byte[0] will add/remove all (existing) groups. First, removing groups is executed. This way, you could leave all groups and join only the ones provided.
Changes become active not immediately but when the server executes this operation (approximately RTT/2).
member.param: Groups to remove from interest. Null will not leave any. A byte[0] will remove all.
Groups to add to interest. Null will not add any. A byte[0] will add all current.

Defines to which interest group the event is sent. Players can subscribe or unsibscribe to groups. Group 0 is always sent to all. Default: 0.
Tells the server to send this event to the "WebHook" configured for your Application in the Dashboard. Should only be used in Turnbased games.
member.returns: If operation could be enqueued for sending. Sent when calling: Service or SendOutgoingCommands.

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.LoadBalancingPeer.OpRaiseEvent(System.Byte,System.Byte,System.Collections.Hashtable,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Send your custom data as event to an "interest group" in the current Room.
member.remarks: No matter if reliable or not, when an event is sent to a interest Group, some users won't get this data. Clients can control the groups they are interested in by using OpChangeGroups.
member.param: Identifies this type of event (and the content). Your game's event codes can start with 0.
The ID of the interest group this event goes to (exclusively).
Custom data you want to send along (use null, if none).
If this event has to arrive reliably (potentially repeated if it's lost).
member.returns: If operation could be enqueued for sending

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.LoadBalancingPeer.OpRaiseEvent(System.Byte,System.Collections.Hashtable,System.Boolean,System.Byte)
member.summary: Used in a room to raise (send) an event to the other players. Multiple overloads expose different parameters to this frequently used operation. This is an async request will trigger a OnOperationResponse() call only in error-cases, because it's called many times per second and can hardly fail.
member.param: Code for this "type" of event (assign a code, "meaning" and content at will, starting at code 1).
Data to send. Hashtable that contains key-values of Photon serializable datatypes.
Use false if the event is replaced by a newer rapidly. Reliable events add overhead and add lag when repeated.
The "channel" to which this event should belong. Per channel, the sequence is kept in order.
member.returns: If the operation could be sent (has to be connected).

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.LoadBalancingPeer.OpRaiseEvent(System.Byte,System.Collections.Hashtable,System.Boolean,System.Byte,System.Int32[])
member.summary: Used in a room to raise (send) an event to the other players. Multiple overloads expose different parameters to this frequently used operation.
member.param: Code for this "type" of event (use a code per "meaning" or content).
Data to send. Hashtable that contains key-values of Photon serializable datatypes.
Use false if the event is replaced by a newer rapidly. Reliable events add overhead and add lag when repeated.
The "channel" to which this event should belong. Per channel, the sequence is kept in order.
Defines the target players who should receive the event (use only for small target groups).
member.returns: If the operation could be sent (has to be connected).

Data to send. Hashtable that contains key-values of Photon serializable datatypes.
Use false if the event is replaced by a newer rapidly. Reliable events add overhead and add lag when repeated.
The "channel" to which this event should belong. Per channel, the sequence is kept in order.
Defines the target players who should receive the event (use only for small target groups).
Use EventCaching options to store this event for players who join.
member.returns: If the operation could be sent (has to be connected).

Data to send. Hashtable that contains key-values of Photon serializable datatypes.
Use false if the event is replaced by a newer rapidly. Reliable events add overhead and add lag when repeated.

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.LoadBalancingPeer.OpRaiseEvent(System.Byte,System.Object,System.Boolean,ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.RaiseEventOptions)
member.summary: Send an event with custom code/type and any content to the other players in the same room.
member.remarks: This override explicitly uses another parameter order to not mix it up with the implementation for Hashtable only.
member.param: Identifies this type of event (and the content). Your game's event codes can start with 0.
Any serializable datatype (including Hashtable like the other OpRaiseEvent overloads).
If this event has to arrive reliably (potentially repeated if it's lost).
Contains (slightly) less often used options. If you pass null, the default options will be used.
member.returns: If operation could be enqueued for sending. Sent when calling: Service or SendOutgoingCommands.

member.name: T:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.RaiseEventOptions
member.summary: Aggregates several less-often used options for operation RaiseEvent. See field descriptions for usage details.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.RaiseEventOptions.Default
member.summary: Default options: CachingOption: DoNotCache, InterestGroup: 0, targetActors: null, receivers: Others, sequenceChannel: 0.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.RaiseEventOptions.CachingOption
member.summary: Defines if the server should simply send the event, put it in the cache or remove events that are like this one.
member.remarks: When using option: SliceSetIndex, SlicePurgeIndex or SlicePurgeUpToIndex, set a CacheSliceIndex. All other options except SequenceChannel get ignored.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.RaiseEventOptions.InterestGroup
member.summary: The number of the Interest Group to send this to. 0 goes to all users but to get 1 and up, clients must subscribe to the group first.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.RaiseEventOptions.TargetActors
member.summary: A list of PhotonPlayer.IDs to send this event to. You can implement events that just go to specific users this way.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.RaiseEventOptions.Receivers
member.summary: Sends the event to All, MasterClient or Others (default). Be careful with MasterClient, as the client might disconnect before it got the event and it gets lost.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.RaiseEventOptions.SequenceChannel
member.summary: Events are ordered per "channel". If you have events that are independent of others, they can go into another sequence or channel.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.RaiseEventOptions.ForwardToWebhook
member.summary: Events can be forwarded to Webhooks, which can evaluate and use the events to follow the game's state.

member.name: T:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.ErrorCode
member.summary: ErrorCode defines the default codes associated with Photon client/server communication.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.ErrorCode.Ok
member.summary: (0) is always "OK", anything else an error or specific situation.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.ErrorCode.OperationNotAllowedInCurrentState
member.summary: (-3) Operation can't be executed yet (e.g. OpJoin can't be called before being authenticated, RaiseEvent cant be used before getting into a room).
member.remarks: Before you call any operations on the Cloud servers, the automated client workflow must complete its authorization. In PUN, wait until State is: JoinedLobby (with AutoJoinLobby = true) or ConnectedToMaster (AutoJoinLobby = false)

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.ErrorCode.InvalidOperationCode
member.summary: (-2) The operation you called is not implemented on the server (application) you connect to. Make sure you run the fitting applications.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.ErrorCode.InternalServerError
member.summary: (-1) Something went wrong in the server. Try to reproduce and contact Exit Games.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.ErrorCode.InvalidAuthentication
member.summary: (32767) Authentication failed. Possible cause: AppId is unknown to Photon (in cloud service).

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.ErrorCode.GameIdAlreadyExists
member.summary: (32766) GameId (name) already in use (can't create another). Change name.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.ErrorCode.GameFull
member.summary: (32765) Game is full. This rarely happens when some player joined the room before your join completed.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.ErrorCode.GameClosed
member.summary: (32764) Game is closed and can't be joined. Join another game.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.ErrorCode.ServerFull
member.summary: (32762) Not in use currently.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.ErrorCode.UserBlocked
member.summary: (32761) Not in use currently.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.ErrorCode.NoRandomMatchFound
member.summary: (32760) Random matchmaking only succeeds if a room exists thats neither closed nor full. Repeat in a few seconds or create a new room.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.ErrorCode.GameDoesNotExist
member.summary: (32758) Join can fail if the room (name) is not existing (anymore). This can happen when players leave while you join.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.ErrorCode.MaxCcuReached
member.summary: (32757) Authorization on the Photon Cloud failed becaus the concurrent users (CCU) limit of the app's subscription is reached.
member.remarks:
Unless you have a plan with "CCU Burst", clients might fail the authentication step during connect. Affected client are unable to call operations. Please note that players who end a game and return to the master server will disconnect and re-connect, which means that they just played and are rejected in the next minute / re-connect. This is a temporary measure. Once the CCU is below the limit, players will be able to connect an play again.
OpAuthorize is part of connection workflow but only on the Photon Cloud, this error can happen. Self-hosted Photon servers with a CCU limited license won't let a client connect at all.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.ErrorCode.InvalidRegion
member.summary: (32756) Authorization on the Photon Cloud failed because the app's subscription does not allow to use a particular region's server.
member.remarks:
Some subscription plans for the Photon Cloud are region-bound. Servers of other regions can't be used then. Check your master server address and compare it with your Photon Cloud Dashboard's info. https://cloud.exitgames.com/dashboard
OpAuthorize is part of connection workflow but only on the Photon Cloud, this error can happen. Self-hosted Photon servers with a CCU limited license won't let a client connect at all.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.ErrorCode.CustomAuthenticationFailed
member.summary: (32755) Custom Authentication of the user failed due to setup reasons (see Cloud Dashboard) or the provided user data (like username or token). Check error message for details.

member.name: T:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.MatchmakingMode
member.summary: Options for matchmaking rules for OpJoinRandom.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.MatchmakingMode.FillRoom
member.summary: Fills up rooms (oldest first) to get players together as fast as possible. Default.
member.remarks: Makes most sense with MaxPlayers > 0 and games that can only start with more players.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.MatchmakingMode.SerialMatching
member.summary: Distributes players across available rooms sequentially but takes filter into account. Without filter, rooms get players evenly distributed.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.MatchmakingMode.RandomMatching
member.summary: Joins a (fully) random room. Expected properties must match but aside from this, any available room might be selected.

member.name: T:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.CustomAuthenticationType
member.summary: Options for optional "Custom Authentication" services used with Photon. Used by OpAuthenticate after connecting to Photon.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.CustomAuthenticationType.Custom
member.summary: Use a custom authentification service. Currently the only implemented option.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.CustomAuthenticationType.Steam
member.summary: Authenticates users by their Steam Account. Set auth values accordingly!

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.CustomAuthenticationType.Facebook
member.summary: Authenticates users by their Facebook Account. Set auth values accordingly!

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.CustomAuthenticationType.None
member.summary: Disables custom authentification. Same as not providing any AuthenticationValues for connect (more precisely for: OpAuthenticate).

member.name: T:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.LobbyType
member.summary: Options of lobby types available. Lobby types might be implemented in certain Photon versions and won't be available on older servers.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.LobbyType.Default
member.summary: This lobby is used unless another is defined by game or JoinRandom. Room-lists will be sent and JoinRandomRoom can filter by matching properties.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.LobbyType.SqlLobby
member.summary: This lobby type lists rooms like Default but JoinRandom has a parameter for SQL-like "where" clauses for filtering. This allows bigger, less, or and and combinations.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.LobbyType.AsyncRandomLobby
member.summary: This lobby does not send lists of games. It is only used for OpJoinRandomRoom. It keeps rooms available for a while when there are only inactive users left.

member.name: T:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.TypedLobby
member.summary: Refers to a specific lobby (and type) on the server.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.TypedLobby.Name
member.summary: Name of the lobby this game gets added to. Default: null, attached to default lobby. Lobbies are unique per lobbyName plus lobbyType, so the same name can be used when several types are existing.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.TypedLobby.Type
member.summary: Type of the (named)lobby this game gets added to

member.name: T:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.RoomOptions
member.summary: Wraps up common room properties needed when you create rooms. Read the individual entries for more details.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.RoomOptions.IsVisible
member.summary: Defines if this room is listed in the lobby. If not, it also is not joined randomly.
member.remarks:
A room that is not visible will be excluded from the room lists that are sent to the clients in lobbies. An invisible room can be joined by name but is excluded from random matchmaking.
Use this to "hide" a room and simulate "private rooms". Players can exchange a roomname and create it invisble to avoid anyone else joining it.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.RoomOptions.IsOpen
member.summary: Defines if this room can be joined at all.
member.remarks: If a room is closed, no player can join this. As example this makes sense when 3 of 4 possible players start their gameplay early and don't want anyone to join during the game. The room can still be listed in the lobby (set isVisible to control lobby-visibility).

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.RoomOptions.MaxPlayers
member.summary: Max number of players that can be in the room at any time. 0 means "no limit".

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.RoomOptions.PlayerTtl
member.summary: Time To Live (TTL) for an 'actor' in a room. If a client disconnects, this actor is inactive first and removed after this timeout. In milliseconds.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.RoomOptions.EmptyRoomTtl
member.summary: Time To Live (TTL) for a room when the last player leaves. Keeps room in memory for case a player re-joins soon. In milliseconds.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.RoomOptions.CheckUserOnJoin
member.summary: Activates UserId checks on joining - allowing a users to be only once in the room.
member.remarks: Turnbased rooms should be created with this check turned on! They should also use custom authentication. Disabled by default for backwards-compatibility.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.RoomOptions.CleanupCacheOnLeave
member.summary: Removes a user's events and properties from the room when a user leaves.
member.remarks: This makes sense when in rooms where players can't place items in the room and just vanish entirely. When you disable this, the event history can become too long to load if the room stays in use indefinitely. Default: true. Cleans up the cache and props of leaving users.

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.RoomOptions.CustomRoomProperties
member.summary: The room's custom properties to set. Use string keys!
member.remarks: Custom room properties are any key-values you need to define the game's setup. The shorter your keys are, the better. Example: Map, Mode (could be "m" when used with "Map"), TileSet (could be "t").

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.RoomOptions.CustomRoomPropertiesForLobby
member.summary: Defines the custom room properties that get listed in the lobby.
member.remarks:
Name the custom room properties that should be available to clients that are in a lobby. Use with care. Unless a custom property is essential for matchmaking or user info, it should not be sent to the lobby, which causes traffic and delays for clients in the lobby.
Default: No custom properties are sent to the lobby.

member.name: T:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.AuthenticationValues
member.summary: Container for "Custom Authentication" values in Photon (default: user and token). Set AuthParameters before connecting - all else is handled.
member.remarks:
Custom Authentication lets you verify end-users by some kind of login or token. It sends those values to Photon which will verify them before granting access or disconnecting the client.
The Photon Cloud Dashboard will let you enable this feature and set important server values for it. https://cloud.exitgames.com/dashboard

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.AuthenticationValues.AuthType
member.summary: The type of custom authentication provider that should be used. Currently only "Custom" or "None" (turns this off).

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.AuthenticationValues.AuthParameters
member.summary: This string must contain any (http get) parameters expected by the used authentication service. By default, username and token.
member.remarks: Standard http get parameters are used here and passed on to the service that's defined in the server (Photon Cloud Dashboard).

member.name: F:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.AuthenticationValues.Secret
member.summary: After initial authentication, Photon provides a secret for this client / user, which is subsequently used as (cached) validation.

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.AuthenticationValues.SetAuthPostData(System.String)
member.summary: Sets the data to be passed-on to the auth service via POST.
member.param: Binary token / auth-data to pass on. Empty string will set AuthPostData to null.

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.AuthenticationValues.SetAuthPostData(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Sets the data to be passed-on to the auth service via POST.
member.param: Binary token / auth-data to pass on.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.AuthenticationValues.AuthPostData
member.summary: Data to be passed-on to the auth service via POST. Default: null (not sent). Either string or byte[] (see setters).

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.Player.ChangeLocalID(System.Int32)
member.summary: Used internally, to update this client's playerID when assigned (doesn't change after assignment).

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.Player.SetCustomProperties(System.Collections.Hashtable)
member.summary: Updates and synchronizes the named properties of this Player with the values of propertiesToSet.
member.remarks:
Any player's properties are available in a Room only and only until the player disconnect or leaves. Access any player's properties by: Player.CustomProperties (read-only!) but don't modify that hashtable.
New properties are added, existing values are updated. Other values will not be changed, so only provide values that changed or are new. To delete a named (custom) property of this player, use null as value. Only string-typed keys are applied (everything else is ignored).
Local cache is updated immediately, other players are updated through Photon with a fitting operation. To reduce network traffic, set only values that actually changed.
member.param: Hashtable of props to udpate, set and sync. See description.

member.name: M:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.Player.SetPlayerNameProperty
member.summary: Uses OpSetPropertiesOfActor to sync this player's name (server is being updated with this.Name).

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.Player.LoadBalancingClient
member.summary: A reference to the LoadbalancingClient which is currently keeping the connection and state.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.Player.RoomReference
member.summary: Used internally to identify the masterclient of a room.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.Player.ID
member.summary: Identifier of this player in current room. Also known as: actorNumber or actorID. It's -1 outside of rooms.
member.remarks: The ID is assigned per room and only valid in that context. It will change even on leave and re-join. IDs are never re-used per room.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.Player.Name
member.summary: Non-unique nickname of this player. Synced automatically in a room and used as fallback-UserId, if that wasn't set.
member.remarks: A player might change his own playername in a room (it's only a property). Setting this value updates the server and other players (using an operation).

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.Player.IsMasterClient
member.summary: The player with the lowest actorID is the master and could be used for special tasks. The LoadBalancingClient.LocalPlayer is not master unless in a room (this is the only player which exists outside of rooms, to store a name).

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.Player.CustomProperties
member.summary: Read-only cache for custom properties of player. Set via Player.SetCustomProperties.
member.remarks: Don't modify the content of this Hashtable. Use SetCustomProperties and the properties of this class to modify values. When you use those, the client will sync values with the server.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.Player.AllProperties
member.summary: Creates a Hashtable with all properties (custom and "well known" ones).
member.remarks: Creates new Hashtables each time used, so if used more often, cache this.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.Player.IsInactive
member.summary: In turnbased games, other players might be inactive in a room. True when another player is not in the current room.

member.name: T:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.Room
member.summary: This class represents a room a client joins/joined. Mostly used through LoadBalancingClient.CurrentRoom, after joining any room. Contains a list of current players, their properties and those of this room, too. A room instance has a number of "well known" properties like IsOpen, MaxPlayers which can be changed. Your own, custom properties can be set via SetCustomProperties() while being in the room.
member.remarks: Typically, this class should be extended by a game-specific implementation with logic and extra features.

member.name: T:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.RoomInfo
member.summary: Used for Room listings of the lobby (not yet joining). Offers the basic info about a room: name, player counts, properties, etc.
member.remarks: This class resembles info about available rooms, as sent by the Master server's lobby. Consider all values as readonly. None are synced (only updated by events by server).

member.summary: State if the local client is already in the game or still going to join it on gameserver (in lobby: false).

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.RoomInfo.MaxPlayers
member.summary: The limit of players for this room. This property is shown in lobby, too. If the room is full (players count == maxplayers), joining this room will fail.
member.remarks: As part of RoomInfo this can't be set. As part of a Room (which the player joined), the setter will update the server and all clients.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.RoomInfo.IsOpen
member.summary: Defines if the room can be joined. This does not affect listing in a lobby but joining the room will fail if not open. If not open, the room is excluded from random matchmaking. Due to racing conditions, found matches might become closed even while you join them. Simply re-connect to master and find another. Use property "IsVisible" to not list the room.
member.remarks: As part of RoomInfo this can't be set. As part of a Room (which the player joined), the setter will update the server and all clients.

member.name: P:ExitGames.Client.Photon.LoadBalancing.RoomInfo.IsVisible
member.summary: Defines if the room is listed in its lobby. Rooms can be created invisible, or changed to invisible. To change if a room can be joined, use property: open.
member.remarks: As part of RoomInfo this can't be set. As part of a Room (which the player joined), the setter will update the server and all clients.

member.summary: Updates and synchronizes the named properties of this Room with the values of propertiesToSet.
member.remarks:
Any player can set a Room's properties. Room properties are available until changed, deleted or until the last player leaves the room. Access them by: Room.CustomProperties (read-only!).
New properties are added, existing values are updated. Other values will not be changed, so only provide values that changed or are new. To delete a named (custom) property of this room, use null as value. Only string-typed keys are applied (everything else is ignored).
Local cache is updated immediately, other clients are updated through Photon with a fitting operation. To reduce network traffic, set only values that actually changed.
member.param: Hashtable of props to udpate, set and sync. See description.

member.remarks: Limit the amount of properties sent to users in the lobby as this improves speed and stability.
